metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Here are the main legal issues extracted from the document:
* Distinctiveness of the trademark "Indirapuram Public School" under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
* Whether the mark is capable of distinguishing the services of one person from those of others.
* Use of trade mark as a geographical name and its implications on registrability.
* Compliance with Rule 25 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017 regarding statement of user in applications.
* Implications of filing a trademark application based on a wrong statement of use.
* Whether the trademark applicant has failed to prove user of the mark since 15/04/2013 through affidavit and documentary evidence.
* Effectiveness of reply and documents filed on record in establishing registrability of the trademark.
* Whether the trade mark is generic or descriptive, and its impact on its ability to acquire distinctive character.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: MVS EduExcellence Pvt Ltd v Registrar of Trademarks**

**Background:** The appellant, MVS EduExcellence Pvt Ltd, had filed an application to register a trademark named "Indirapuram Public School" in Class 41 with the Registrar of Trademarks in Delhi. The application was rejected by the learned Senior Examiner on January 13, 2020.

**Legal Issues:**

1. **Distinctiveness of the mark:** The issue at hand is whether the mark "Indirapuram Public School" lacks distinctiveness and falls under the absolute ground of refusal as per Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
2. **Compliance with Rule 25 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017:** The examiner raised an objection that the applicant had failed to comply with the provision of Rule 25 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017, which requires a statement of user and supporting documents for marks claimed prior to the date of application.

**Arguments:**

* **Appellant's counsel**: Argued that the mark "Indirapuram Public School" has acquired distinctiveness through use since 15th April 2013. He submitted that the examiner had considered the reply to examination report, hearing submissions, and records placed on the portal.
* **Examiner's objection**: Contended that the mark lacks distinctiveness as it is a common surname/personal name/geographical name ornamental/non-distinctive geometrical figure. The examiner highlighted that the applicant failed to provide sufficient evidence of user through affidavit and documentary evidence.

**Court Findings:**

1. **Distinctiveness:** The court held that the mark "Indirapuram Public School" lacks distinctiveness and falls under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
2. **Compliance with Rule 25**: The court observed that the applicant had filed an affidavit proving user since April 15th, 2013, but failed to comply with Rule 25 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017.

**Decision:**

* **Rejection of application**: The Delhi High Court upheld the rejection of the appellant's trademark registration application for "Indirapuram Public School".
* **Grounds for rejection**: The court relied on Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 and observed that the mark lacked distinctiveness. Additionally, the applicant failed to comply with Rule 25 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017.

The decision highlights the importance of complying with the provisions of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017, particularly in providing a statement of user and supporting documents for claimed prior use of a mark.
metadata.full_text:
--- PAGE 1 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 1 of 8 
 
$~7 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
+  
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022 
 
MVS EDUEXCELLENCE PVT LTD. 
     ..... Appellant 
Through: 
Mr. Anuj Kumar and Mr. Abhijeet 
Kumar Pandey, Advs. 
 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
THE REGISTRAR OFTRADEMARKS, DELHI 
..... Respondents 
 
 
 
 
Through: 
 
 
CORAM: 
 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE C. HARI SHANKAR 
 
 
 
 
JUDGEMENT (ORAL) 
% 
 
 
 
         06.02.2023 
 
 
1. 
This appeal challenges order dated 13th January 2020, whereby 
Application No. 3018041, submitted by the appellant for registration of 
the mark “Indirapuram Public School” in Class 41 has been rejected by 
the learned Senior Examiner in the office of the Trade Marks Registry. 
The reasoning in the impugned order of the learned Senior Examiner 
reads as under: 
 
“In the examination report, mark was clearly lacks distinctiveness and 
falls within the purview of Absolute ground of refusal so envisaged 
under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Mars Act, 1999 which is 
reproduced as under :- 
 
9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act 19999 as the mark is a common 
surname/personal name/geographical name/ornamental or a non-
distinctive geometrical figure and as such it is not capable of 
distinguishing the goods or services of one person from those of 
others. 
Subsequently, a hearing was fixed in the matter on 19th March, 2019, 
eventually the Counsel for the applicant appeared on the said date for 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:07.02.2023
15:20:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 2 of 8 
 
hearing and made his oral submissions in support the application. I 
have carefully perused the reply to examination report filed in the 
matter as well as electronically filed records and material available on 
the portal. I have also considered the oral submissions made at the 
time of hearing by the Ld. Counsel for the applicant in support of the 
registrability of the impugned mark. 
 
Since the trade mark applied for registration is clearly lacks 
distinctiveness and descriptive to the nature and description of 
services, as applied for registration and the reply and documents 
placed on record are not sufficient to proceed the application further, 
hence, the mark cannot be allowed to proceed for registration, while 
considering the following. 
 
Incapable of distinguishing the services of one person from the other; 
The trademark “INDIRAPURAM PUBLIC SCHOOL” is a common 
and generic combination of two English words “INDIRAPURAM and 
PUBLIC SCHOOL”. The word INIDRAPURAM is indicated 
geographical place and PUBLIC SCHOOL is indicated of intended 
purpose of services and it does not carry any distinctive character; 
No one can acquire a monopoly or exclusive right; 
 
It is pertinent and thus noteworthy that the impugned application has 
been filed claiming user of the mark since 15/04/2013, thus it was 
incumbent upon the applicant to prove said user through affidavit and 
documentary evidence, otherwise the application would be deemed to 
have been filed on the basis of wrong statement of use. Perusal of 
Examination report reply as well as documents filed on record, I have 
no hesitation to state that affidavit has been filed by the applicant 
which prove the user of the impugned mark since 15/04/2013, 
therefore Applicant has failed to comply with provision of Rule 25 of 
the Trade Marks Rules 2017 which reads as follows: 
 
Rule 25 of Trade Marks Rules, 2017- 
 
Statement of user in applications – (1) An application to register a 
trademark shall, unless the trademark is proposed to be used, contain a 
statement of the period during which , and the person by whom it has 
been used in respect of all the goods or services mentioned in the 
application. 
(2) In case, the use of the trademark is claimed prior to the date of 
application, the applicant shall file an affidavit testifying to such use 
along with supporting documents. 
 
In the light of the above said provision and the observations made by 
the Hon’ble Delhi High Court in the judgments namely Vivek 
Kochher & Anr v M/s Kyk Corporation Ltd & Anr. Reported as PTC 
2017 (72) page 556 and Suresh Kumar Jain Vs. Union of India 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:07.02.2023
15:20:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 3 of 8 
 
reported as PTC 2012(49) page 287, whereby it was held by the 
Hon’ble High Court that if the a mark is filed/registered on the basis of 
wrong statement of use, then the same cannot be registered or remain 
on the Register. Such mark therefore ought not to be put on the 
Register which is essential for a Hearing Officer for the purposes of 
maintaining the purity of Register being acting on behalf of Registrar 
of Trade Marks who is custodian of Register of Trade Marks, as has 
been held by Hon’ble Supreme Court in Hardie Trading Ltd. and 
another v. Addisons paint & Chemicals Ltd., (2003) 11 SCC 92. And 
further in the matter of Inter lkea Systems BV & Anr versus Sham 
Murari &ors, reported as PTC 2018, the Hon’ble Delhi High Court 
observed that “While this Court does not wish to encourage any party, 
which misleads the trademark authorities”. 
 
In view of above, I am of the considered view that objections raised in 
the Examination reports cannot be waived and the Reply to the 
Examination report and documents filed as well as oral submission 
made are insufficient to grant registration of trade mark applied for 
registration, therefore not entitled for any benefit under Section 9(1) 
proviso of the Act. Hence objection under Section 9(1)(a) of the Act 
cannot be waived off. Also the mark cannot be allowed to be 
proceeded further while maintaining the purity of the register.” 
 
2. 
Consequent to submission of its application No. 3018041, seeking 
registration of the “Indirapuram Public School” mark, First Examination 
Report (FER) dated  12th May 2016 was issued from the office of the 
learned Registrar, raising, as the sole objection under Section 9(1)(a)1 of 
the Trade Marks Act, 1999, the contention that the mark, of which 
registration had been sought, was “a common surname/personal 
name/geographical name/ornamental or a non-distinctive geometrical 
                                          
1 9.  
Absolute grounds for refusal of registration. –  
(1)  
The trade marks –  
(a)  
which are devoid of any distinctive character, that is to say, not capable of 
distinguishing the goods or services of one person from those of another person; 
(b)  
which consist exclusively of marks or indications which may serve in trade to 
designate the kind, quality, quantity, intended purpose, values, geographical origin or the time 
of production of the goods or rendering of the service or other characteristics of the goods or 
service; 
(c)  
which consist exclusively of marks or indications which have become customary in 
the current language or in the bona fide and established practices of the trade, 
shall not be registered: 
Provided that a trade mark shall not be refused registration if before the date of application for 
registration it has acquired a distinctive character as a result of the use made of it or is a well-known 
trade mark. 
 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:07.02.2023
15:20:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 4 of 8 
 
figure” which was “not capable of distinguishing the goods or services of 
one person from those of others”. 
 
3. 
The appellant replied to the aforesaid objections on 13th December 
2016. It was asserted, in the reply, that the mark “Indirapuram Public 
School” had gained distinctiveness over a period of time by extensive use 
and was a source indicator for residents residing in the area. Following 
on the reputation gained by it, the reply asserted that further branches of 
the school had been opened at Crossing Republic and at Pratap Vihar, 
Ghaziabad. It was further asserted that over 2,600 students were enrolled 
in the school, which earned substantial income from the educational 
services rendered by it. 
 
4. 
In these circumstances, it was asserted that the objection regarding 
non-distinctiveness, under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act was 
without substance and that, therefore, the mark was entitled to registered. 
 
5. 
The aforesaid reply was accompanied by an affidavit dated 15th 
December 2016. A separate affidavit, by way of evidence, was also filed 
by the appellant, basically reiterating the contents of the aforesaid reply 
dated 13th December 2016. 
 
6. 
Several documents were also filed by the appellant along with the 
aforesaid affidavit. 
 
7. 
Mr. Anuj Kumar, learned Counsel for the appellant submits that 
the impugned order is patently erroneous, as it proceeds by bifurcating 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:07.02.2023
15:20:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 5 of 8 
 
the mark of which registration was sought, into “Indirapuram” and 
“Public School” separately, and holds the mark to be lacking in 
distinctiveness on the ground that Indirapuram was the name of a 
geographical area and “Public School” merely indicated the nature of 
services rendered by the institution for which the application for 
registration had been submitted. 
 
8. 
The mark “Indirapuram Public School” seen as a whole, submits 
Mr. Kumar, is clearly distinctive. He points out that there was no 
objection on the ground that any other institution had a deceptively 
similar name. He also points out that there are several similar marks 
which already stand registered such as Delhi Public School, Ghaziabad 
Public School Senior Secondary School, Mumbai Public School, Indore 
Public School and Chennai Public School. 
 
9. 
Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, learned Counsel for the 
respondent, fairly leaves this aspect to the Court. However, he points out 
that the impugned order also notes that the appellant had not provided 
evidence of user as required by  Rule 272 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017 
(“the 2017 TM Rules”), though there appears to be a typographical error 
in the impugned order in that regard. 
 
10. 
Rule 25(2) of the 2017 TM Rules, as it stands now, specifically 
requires the appellant to file an affidavit testifying to prior user of the 
mark of which registration was sought along with supporting documents. 
                                          
2 27. Statement of user in applications.- 
An application to register a trade mark shall, unless the trade 
mark is proposed to be used, contain a statement of the period during which, and the person by whom it has been 
used in respect of the goods or services mentioned in the application. The Registrar may require the applicant to 
file an affidavit testifying to such user with exhibits showing the mark as used. " 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:07.02.2023
15:20:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 6 of 8 
 
Mr. Anuj Kumar submits that, at the time when the application for 
registration had been filed by his client, on 28th July 2015, the Rule 25(2) 
of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017 had yet to come into force and that Rule 
273 of the then existing Trade Marks Rules, 2002 (“the 2002 TM Rules”) 
then in force, did not require, mandatorily, filing of an affidavit of user, 
but clothed the Registrar with the discretion (as is apparent from the use 
of the word “may”) to require the applicant to file an affidavit of user 
with supportive exhibits.   
 
11. 
Mr. Vaidyanathan, learned Counsel for the respondent submits 
that, however, as the evidence in affidavit was filed by the appellant after 
2017, the appellant ought to have placed evidence of prior user on record. 
 
12. 
Given the fact that the application was filed prior to the 
requirement of affidavit of user along with supportive evidence being 
placed on record, where prior user was claimed, I am inclined to agree 
with Mr. Anuj Kumar that the appellant cannot be faulted for not having 
filed such an affidavit with evidence of user. It is trite that an application 
or petition would be governed by the procedure, or format, applicable at 
the time when it is filed, and that subsequent changes in procedure or 
format introducing during the pendency of the application would not 
affect it. Besides, Rule 1584 of the 2017 TM Rules saves acts done under 
the 2002 TM Rules before the 2017 TM Rules came into force. This 
itself is a complete answer to Mr. Vaidyanathan’s submission. 
                                          
3 27.  
Statement of user in applications. – An application to register a trade mark shall, unless the trade mark 
is proposed to be used, contain a statement of the period during which, and the person by whom it has been used 
in respect of the goods or services mentioned in the application. The Registrar may require the applicant to file an 
affidavit testifying to such user with exhibits showing the mark as used. 
4 158. 
The Trade Marks Rules, 2002, are hereby repealed without prejudice to anything done under such rules 
before the coming into force of these rules. 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:07.02.2023
15:20:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 7 of 8 
 
13. 
Be that as it may, this Court, vide its order dated 9th September 
2022, permitted the appellant to place user documents on record. The 
appellant has thereafter, filed, under index dated 29th October 2022, a list 
of the documents which, according to the appellant, evidence prior user, 
by the appellant, of the “Indirapuram Public School” word mark since 
2014, being the claim of user submitted before the learned Registrar. 
 
14. 
It would be appropriate that the claim of prior user by the 
appellant, predicated on the aforesaid documents, be considered in the 
first instance by the learned Registrar, as it primarily involves 
examination into facts. 
 
15. 
The impugned order, insofar as it rejects the appellant’s 
application under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act, on the ground 
that the “Indirapuram Public School” mark is lacking indistinctiveness is, 
however, not sustainable on facts or in law. 
 
16. 
As such, the impugned order dated 13th January 2020 is quashed 
and set aside. Application No. 3018041 filed by the appellant shall stand 
remanded for reconsideration by the learned Registrar or by any officer 
deputed by the learned Registrar for the said purpose, solely on the aspect 
of user as claimed by the appellant since 2014. The appellant would file a 
fresh affidavit of user before the learned Registrar. The learned Registrar 
would examine the claim of user of the appellant on the basis of the said 
affidavit along with the documents already filed before the learned 
Registrar as well as the documents filed before this Court under cover of 
index dated 29th October 2022, which the appellant is permitted to 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:07.02.2023
15:20:02
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 8 of 8 
 
present before the learned Registrar for the said purpose. 
 
17. 
The appellant would also be granted an opportunity of hearing 
before any decision is taken. For the said purpose, let the appellant 
present itself before the learned Registrar on 21st February 2023. 
 
18. 
The learned Registrar (or other officer deputed by him) is directed 
to decide the appellant’s application as expeditiously as possible, 
preferably within a period of four weeks therefrom. 
 
19. 
The appeal stands allowed to the aforesaid extent with no order as 
to costs. 
 
20. 
Judgment to be uploaded on the website of this Court within 24 
hours. 
 
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J 
 
FEBRUARY 6, 2023 
 
AR 
 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:07.02.2023
15:20:02
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary: MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks**

The case is a trademark registration appeal (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022) filed by MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. against the decision of the Trade Marks Registry to reject their application for registration of the mark "Indirapuram Public School" in Class 41.

**Facts:**

* The applicant, MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd., filed an application (Application No. 3018041) on January 13, 2019, for registration of the mark "Indirapuram Public School."
* The Trade Marks Registry rejected the application on January 13, 2020, citing that the mark lacks distinctiveness and falls under the absolute ground of refusal under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
* A hearing was held on March 19, 2019, where the applicant's counsel made oral submissions in support of the application.

**Arguments:**

* The respondent, The Registrar of Trade Marks, Delhi, argued that the mark is a common surname/personal name/geographical name/ornamental or non-distinctive geometrical figure and cannot distinguish the services of one person from others.
* The applicant's counsel argued that they had proved user of the mark since April 15, 2013, which should be considered.

**Decision:**

* The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi (C. HARI SHANKAR, J.) dismissed the appeal on February 6, 2023.
* The court held that the applicant failed to comply with Rule 25 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017, which requires a statement of user in applications.

**Parties:**

* Appellant: MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd.
* Respondent: The Registrar of Trade Marks, Delhi

**Dates:**

*

nodes.title: Page 2
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 2 from the PDF document:

**MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd vs The Registrar of Trade Marks**

The Court's reasoning for rejecting the trademark application is as follows:

* The trademark "INDIRAPURAM PUBLIC SCHOOL" lacks distinctiveness and descriptive to the nature and description of services.
* The name is a common and generic combination of two English words.
* There is no distinctive character in the mark, indicating it cannot distinguish one person's services from another.

The applicant has failed to comply with Rule 25 of the Trade Marks Rules 2017, as they have not provided sufficient evidence of user since April 15, 2013. The rule requires an affidavit and supporting documents for claimed prior use.

The court has considered similar judgments, including **Vivek Kochher** (PTC 2017) and **Suresh Kumar Jain vs Union of India**, in making this decision.

Source: PDF document "37. MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf"

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
**Case:** MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks (2023/DHC/000853)

**Background:**

MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. applied to register the trade mark "Indirapuram Public School" in 2016. The Registrar of Trade Marks raised an objection under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, citing that the mark was not capable of distinguishing goods or services of one person from another.

**Proceedings:**

The matter came up for hearing before Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. HARI SHANKAR of the Delhi High Court.

**Arguments and Ruling:**

The appellant argued that despite being a common name, the mark had gained distinctiveness through extensive use and reputation. However, the learned Judge rejected this contention, citing the doctrine of "purity of Register". The Court also relied on precedents such as Hardie Trading Ltd. v. Addisons Paint & Chemicals Ltd. (2003) 11 SCC 92 and Inter IKEA Systems BV v. Sham Murari (2018).

**Decision:**

The Court held that the objections raised in the Examination Report cannot be waived off, and therefore, the mark cannot be registered. The decision is based on the principle of maintaining the purity of the Register.

**Relevant Information:**

* Case Number: C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022
* Date: February 7, 2023
* PDF Source: MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks (2023/DHC/000853)

**Note:** The extracted information is based on the provided PDF snippet and may not be comprehensive or represent the complete case proceedings.
tree_structure.pdf_source: 37. MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
Here's a summary of page 3 from the PDF:

**Case:** MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks (2023/DHC/000853)

**Background:**

The Hon'ble High Court in **P.A. Educational Trust vs. M/S Shiksha Nidhi Charitable and Religious Trust & Others**, reported as PTC 2012(49) page 287, held that a mark cannot be registered if filed on the basis of a wrong statement of use. The purity of the Register must be maintained.

The Court also cited **Inter lkea Systems BV v. Sham Murari &ors** (PTC 2018), where it was observed that the Court does not encourage any party that misleads trademark authorities.

**Decision:**

Based on these precedents, the Court decided that objections raised in the Examination reports cannot be waived and that the Reply to the Examination report and documents filed, along with oral submissions made, are insufficient to grant registration of the trade mark applied for. The objection under Section 9(1)(a) of the Act cannot be waived off.

**Source:** MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks (PDF: 37 MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 3 of 8 
 
reported as PTC 2012(49) page 287, whereby it was held by the 
Hon’ble High Court that if the a mark is filed/registered on the basis of 
wrong statement of use, then the same cannot be registered or remain 
on the Register. Such mark therefore ought not to be put on the 
Register which is essential for a Hearing Officer for the purposes of 
maintaining the purity of Register being acting on behalf of Registrar 
of Trade Marks who is custodian of Register of Trade Marks, as has 
been held by Hon’ble Supreme Court in Hardie Trading Ltd. and 
another v. Addisons paint & Chemicals Ltd., (2003) 11 SCC 92. And 
further in the matter of Inter lkea Systems BV & Anr versus Sham 
Murari &ors, reported as PTC 2018, the Hon’ble Delhi High Court 
observed that “While this Court does not wish to encourage any party, 
which misleads the trademark authorities”. 
 
In view of above, I am of the considered view that objections raised in 
the Examination reports cannot be waived and the Reply to the 
Examination report and documents filed as well as oral submission 
made are insufficient to grant registration of trade mark applied for 
registration, therefore not entitled for any benefit under Section 9(1) 
proviso of the Act. Hence objection under Section 9(1)(a) of the Act 
cannot be waived off. Also the mark cannot be allowed to be 
proceeded further while maintaining the purity of the register.” 
 
2. 
Consequent to submission of its application No. 3018041, seeking 
registration of the “Indirapuram Public School” mark, First Examination 
Report (FER) dated  12th May 2016 was issued from the office of the 
learned Registrar, raising, as the sole objection under Section 9(1)(a)1 of 
the Trade Marks Act, 1999, the contention that the mark, of which 
registration had been sought, was “a common surname/personal 
name/geographical name/ornamental or a non-distinctive geometrical 
                                          
1 9.  
Absolute grounds for refusal of registration. –  
(1)  
The trade marks –  
(a)  
which are devoid of any distinctive character, that is to say, not capable of 
distinguishing the goods or services of one person from those of another person; 
(b)  
which consist exclusively of marks or indications which may serve in trade to 
designate the kind, quality, quantity, intended purpose, values, geographical origin or the time 
of production of the goods or rendering of the service or other characteristics of the goods or 
service; 
(c)  
which consist exclusively of marks or indications which have become customary in 
the current language or in the bona fide and established practices of the trade, 
shall not be registered: 
Provided that a trade mark shall not be refused registration if before the date of application for 
registration it has acquired a distinctive character as a result of the use made of it or is a well-known 
trade mark. 
 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:07.02.2023
15:20:02
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 4 from the PDF:
MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks:

The appellant submitted that the objection regarding non-distinctiveness (Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act) was without substance, as "Indirapuram Public School" had gained distinctiveness over time through extensive use and reputation. They asserted that their school in Indirapuram had:

* Enrolled over 2,600 students, earning substantial income.
* Gained a reputation as a source indicator for residents in the area.

They filed affidavits dated December 13 and 15, 2016, with accompanying documents to support their claim. The case was further submitted by Mr. Anuj Kumar, learned Counsel for the appellant.

Source:
37. MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf (Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000853)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 4 of 8 
 
figure” which was “not capable of distinguishing the goods or services of 
one person from those of others”. 
 
3. 
The appellant replied to the aforesaid objections on 13th December 
2016. It was asserted, in the reply, that the mark “Indirapuram Public 
School” had gained distinctiveness over a period of time by extensive use 
and was a source indicator for residents residing in the area. Following 
on the reputation gained by it, the reply asserted that further branches of 
the school had been opened at Crossing Republic and at Pratap Vihar, 
Ghaziabad. It was further asserted that over 2,600 students were enrolled 
in the school, which earned substantial income from the educational 
services rendered by it. 
 
4. 
In these circumstances, it was asserted that the objection regarding 
non-distinctiveness, under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act was 
without substance and that, therefore, the mark was entitled to registered. 
 
5. 
The aforesaid reply was accompanied by an affidavit dated 15th 
December 2016. A separate affidavit, by way of evidence, was also filed 
by the appellant, basically reiterating the contents of the aforesaid reply 
dated 13th December 2016. 
 
6. 
Several documents were also filed by the appellant along with the 
aforesaid affidavit. 
 
7. 
Mr. Anuj Kumar, learned Counsel for the appellant submits that 
the impugned order is patently erroneous, as it proceeds by bifurcating 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
Here is a summary of the provided section from the PDF document: MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks,

**Case Details:**

* Court: High Court of Delhi
* Case No.: C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000853

**Background:**
MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. (Appellant) applied for trade mark registration but was rejected by the Registrar of Trade Marks, Delhi (Respondent).

**Arguments:**

The Appellant's advocate, Mr. Anuj Kumar, argued that the mark "Indirapuram Public School" is distinctive and not lacking distinctiveness as the geographical area "Indirapuram" does not render it generic.

However,

* The Respondent's advocate, Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, pointed out that the Appellant failed to provide evidence of user (Rule 272 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017).
* A typographical error was noted in the impugned order regarding Rule 25(2) requirements.

**Key Legal Points:**

* Rule 25(2) specifically requires prior user affidavit along with supporting documents for trade mark registration applications.
* However, at the time of application (July 28, 2015), Rule 25(2) had not come into force and Rule 273 of the then existing Trade Marks Rules, 2002 required discretion to request an affidavit.
* The Court agreed with Mr. Anuj Kumar that the Appellant was exempted from filing prior user evidence.

**Decision:**

The Court ruled in favor of the Appellant, stating that they cannot be faulted for not having filed prior user evidence due to changes in procedure and applicable rules at the time of application.

PDF Source: 37. MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf
tree_structure.pdf_source: 37. MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 5 from the PDF "37. MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf":

The High Court of Delhi heard a case regarding trademark registration for "Indirapuram Public School". 

**Arguments:**

* Mr. Kumar, counsel for the petitioner (MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd), argued that when the mark is considered as a whole ("Indirapuram Public School"), it is distinctive.
* He pointed out that there are similar marks already registered, such as "Delhi Public School" and "Chennai Public School".

**Counsel for Respondent:**

* Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar left the distinctiveness aspect to the Court but noted that the petitioner had not provided evidence of user as required by Rule 272 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017.

**Rule cited:** 

* Rule 25(2) of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017 (dated February 7, 2023, digitally signed)

PDF source: 

37. MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 5 of 8 
 
the mark of which registration was sought, into “Indirapuram” and 
“Public School” separately, and holds the mark to be lacking in 
distinctiveness on the ground that Indirapuram was the name of a 
geographical area and “Public School” merely indicated the nature of 
services rendered by the institution for which the application for 
registration had been submitted. 
 
8. 
The mark “Indirapuram Public School” seen as a whole, submits 
Mr. Kumar, is clearly distinctive. He points out that there was no 
objection on the ground that any other institution had a deceptively 
similar name. He also points out that there are several similar marks 
which already stand registered such as Delhi Public School, Ghaziabad 
Public School Senior Secondary School, Mumbai Public School, Indore 
Public School and Chennai Public School. 
 
9. 
Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, learned Counsel for the 
respondent, fairly leaves this aspect to the Court. However, he points out 
that the impugned order also notes that the appellant had not provided 
evidence of user as required by  Rule 272 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017 
(“the 2017 TM Rules”), though there appears to be a typographical error 
in the impugned order in that regard. 
 
10. 
Rule 25(2) of the 2017 TM Rules, as it stands now, specifically 
requires the appellant to file an affidavit testifying to prior user of the 
mark of which registration was sought along with supporting documents. 
                                          
2 27. Statement of user in applications.- 
An application to register a trade mark shall, unless the trade 
mark is proposed to be used, contain a statement of the period during which, and the person by whom it has been 
used in respect of the goods or services mentioned in the application. The Registrar may require the applicant to 
file an affidavit testifying to such user with exhibits showing the mark as used. " 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:07.02.2023
15:20:02
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 37. MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 6**

Source: MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022 (PDF: 37)

On page 6, the following facts and proceedings are summarized:

* Mr. Anuj Kumar for the appellant submits that the rule requiring an affidavit of user had not come into force yet when the application was filed on July 28, 2015.
* Rule 25(2) of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017 had not been implemented at that time.
* The then-existing Rule 273 of the Trade Marks Rules, 2002 gave the Registrar discretion to require an affidavit of user with supportive exhibits.
* Mr. Vaidyanathan for the respondent submits that evidence of prior user was filed after 2017 and should have been placed on record earlier.

The Court agrees with Mr. Anuj Kumar, holding that the procedure applicable at the time of filing the application (2002 TM Rules) governs it, and subsequent changes do not affect it. Additionally, Rule 1584 of the 2017 TM Rules saves acts done under the 2002 TM Rules before its implementation.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 6 of 8 
 
Mr. Anuj Kumar submits that, at the time when the application for 
registration had been filed by his client, on 28th July 2015, the Rule 25(2) 
of the Trade Marks Rules, 2017 had yet to come into force and that Rule 
273 of the then existing Trade Marks Rules, 2002 (“the 2002 TM Rules”) 
then in force, did not require, mandatorily, filing of an affidavit of user, 
but clothed the Registrar with the discretion (as is apparent from the use 
of the word “may”) to require the applicant to file an affidavit of user 
with supportive exhibits.   
 
11. 
Mr. Vaidyanathan, learned Counsel for the respondent submits 
that, however, as the evidence in affidavit was filed by the appellant after 
2017, the appellant ought to have placed evidence of prior user on record. 
 
12. 
Given the fact that the application was filed prior to the 
requirement of affidavit of user along with supportive evidence being 
placed on record, where prior user was claimed, I am inclined to agree 
with Mr. Anuj Kumar that the appellant cannot be faulted for not having 
filed such an affidavit with evidence of user. It is trite that an application 
or petition would be governed by the procedure, or format, applicable at 
the time when it is filed, and that subsequent changes in procedure or 
format introducing during the pendency of the application would not 
affect it. Besides, Rule 1584 of the 2017 TM Rules saves acts done under 
the 2002 TM Rules before the 2017 TM Rules came into force. This 
itself is a complete answer to Mr. Vaidyanathan’s submission. 
                                          
3 27.  
Statement of user in applications. – An application to register a trade mark shall, unless the trade mark 
is proposed to be used, contain a statement of the period during which, and the person by whom it has been used 
in respect of the goods or services mentioned in the application. The Registrar may require the applicant to file an 
affidavit testifying to such user with exhibits showing the mark as used. 
4 158. 
The Trade Marks Rules, 2002, are hereby repealed without prejudice to anything done under such rules 
before the coming into force of these rules. 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:07.02.2023
15:20:02
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
The document is a court decision from the High Court of Delhi dated February 6, 2023 (Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000853). The case is MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.

**Background:**

MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. filed an application under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act to register a word mark "Indirapuram Public School". The Registrar of Trade Marks rejected the application due to alleged lack of distinctiveness.

**Court Decision:**

The High Court allowed the appeal, set aside the impugned order, and remanded the matter for reconsideration by the learned Registrar. The court held that:

* The appellant's claim of prior user since 2014 should be considered by the learned Registrar.
* The application was rejected on a wrong ground (lack of distinctiveness).
* A fresh affidavit of user should be filed by the appellant before the learned Registrar.
* The learned Registrar should examine the claim of user based on the new affidavit and documents already filed.
* The appellant will have an opportunity to present itself before the learned Registrar on February 21, 2023.

**Key Facts:**

* Date of the court decision: February 6, 2023
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000853
* Case number: C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022
* Parties involved:
	+ MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd.
	+ The Registrar of Trade Marks
* Dates mentioned in the document:
	+ October 29, 2022 (index date)
	+ November 9, 2022 (date of permitting user documents on record)

**PDF Source:**

37. MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf
tree_structure.pdf_source: 37. MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd. v. The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 7 from the PDF:

**Case Details**

* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000853
* Case Name: MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd v The Registrar of Trade Marks
* Court: High Court of Delhi at New Delhi
* Order Date: September 9, 2022

**Proceedings**

* The appellant was permitted to file user documents on record.
* The appellant submitted a list of documents claiming prior user since 2014.
* The learned Registrar will examine the claim of user.

**Decisions**

* The impugned order is quashed and set aside, as it rejects the application under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act on the ground that the mark "Indirapuram Public School" lacks indistinctiveness.
* Application No. 3018041 is remanded for reconsideration by the learned Registrar or an officer deputed by them, solely on the aspect of user as claimed by the appellant since 2014.

**References**

From PDF: 37. MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd v The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 7 of 8 
 
13. 
Be that as it may, this Court, vide its order dated 9th September 
2022, permitted the appellant to place user documents on record. The 
appellant has thereafter, filed, under index dated 29th October 2022, a list 
of the documents which, according to the appellant, evidence prior user, 
by the appellant, of the “Indirapuram Public School” word mark since 
2014, being the claim of user submitted before the learned Registrar. 
 
14. 
It would be appropriate that the claim of prior user by the 
appellant, predicated on the aforesaid documents, be considered in the 
first instance by the learned Registrar, as it primarily involves 
examination into facts. 
 
15. 
The impugned order, insofar as it rejects the appellant’s 
application under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act, on the ground 
that the “Indirapuram Public School” mark is lacking indistinctiveness is, 
however, not sustainable on facts or in law. 
 
16. 
As such, the impugned order dated 13th January 2020 is quashed 
and set aside. Application No. 3018041 filed by the appellant shall stand 
remanded for reconsideration by the learned Registrar or by any officer 
deputed by the learned Registrar for the said purpose, solely on the aspect 
of user as claimed by the appellant since 2014. The appellant would file a 
fresh affidavit of user before the learned Registrar. The learned Registrar 
would examine the claim of user of the appellant on the basis of the said 
affidavit along with the documents already filed before the learned 
Registrar as well as the documents filed before this Court under cover of 
index dated 29th October 2022, which the appellant is permitted to 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 8 from the PDF file:

This page concludes the judgment in the case MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd v. The Registrar of Trade Marks (2023/DHC/000853).

**Key points:**

* The learned Registrar is directed to hold a meeting with the appellant to discuss its application ( para 17).
* The appellant is granted an opportunity of hearing before any decision is taken (para 16, not included on page 8 but relevant for understanding).
* The learned Registrar is directed to decide the appeal as expeditiously as possible within four weeks from the date of the order (para 18).
* Costs are not awarded against either party (para 19).

**Judgment details:**

* Case number: C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000853
* Judgement dated: February 6, 2023
* Signed by Justice C. HARI SHANKAR

**PDF source:** (37. MVS Eduexcellence Pvt Ltd.v The Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000853 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 148/2022                                              Page 8 of 8 
 
present before the learned Registrar for the said purpose. 
 
17. 
The appellant would also be granted an opportunity of hearing 
before any decision is taken. For the said purpose, let the appellant 
present itself before the learned Registrar on 21st February 2023. 
 
18. 
The learned Registrar (or other officer deputed by him) is directed 
to decide the appellant’s application as expeditiously as possible, 
preferably within a period of four weeks therefrom. 
 
19. 
The appeal stands allowed to the aforesaid extent with no order as 
to costs. 
 
20.

hours. 
 
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J
